abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Republic of Cyprus' Transport
            Sector Development Project. Its primary objectives were: (a)
            increasing the efficiency of the transport sector operating
            system; (b) improving cost recovery in revenue earning
            transport sector operations and in the highway system; (c)
            enhancing the quality of transport planning and project
            implementation, including attention being paid to
            environmental issues; (d) upgrading priority areas of the
            transport infrastructure to support economic growth and
            social change in a cost effective way; and (e) increasing
            the extent and quality of training provided for personnel in
            the roads, road transport and civil aviation sub-sectors.
            The project was well designed in relation to the stage of
            development of the transport sector in Cyprus, was
            successfully implemented, achieved the high ERR expected at
            appraisal and, given the Government's continued
            commitment, is likely to be sustainable. There are still
            lessons to be learned and issues to be addressed. For the
            Government: (a) Procurement procedures are slow and costly
            and should be improved. (b) Greater autonomy should be given
            by supervising ministries to the executing and revenue
            earning entities. (c) There should be greater public
            participation at an earlier stage in the planning process,
            especially where land acquisition is involved. For the Bank:
            a) The Bank can make an effective contribution to
            institutional reform only through a series of projects and
            with a willing partner. However as a country approaches
            graduation, the Bank's leverage declines.  b) Project
            supervision should pay greater attention to the policy
            components which are important even though the amount of
            funding allocated is low. c) By showing flexibility the Bank
            was able to help the Borrower reallocate funds from a
            component unlikely to make progress to a new component of
            international importance.
